title: Is mind-body dualism just a philosophical question or is there scientific evidence to support it? - Quora

response.answer_text: Mind-Body Dualism seems, on the surface, similar to the concept that the physical world is an illusion of the senses, that the mind can conceive and perceive things that do not physically exist. However after more reading it becomes clear that Mind-Body Dualism is a rather more abstract idea. Where the concept of sensory data being illusory is, somewhat, supported by the manner in which the brain functions, Mind-Body Dualism states that the mind, or consciousness, is a non-physical entity, that the processes and functions by which we experience consciousness belong to a wholly non-physical entity, Plato described multiple “Souls” that process and experience different stimuli. But this concept simply doesn’t stand up to scrutiny. We know how the brain performs sensory processes, we can watch it in action, we can track the physical processes that lead to thought and experience which, ultimately, proves Mind-Body Dualism false as if you can see a physical thought, then the mind cannot be a non-physical entity.
It not even a SERIOUS philosophical question, as the concept is half-baked. It’s just a religious beief disguised as philosophy. There is no scientific evidence whatsoever to support the idea.
